definition:
Let $X$ be a subset of ${\mathbb{R}}$. We say that $X$ is bounded when
there exists a real number $M$ such that $|x|<M$ for all $x\in X$. When
$X$ is an interval, we speak of a bounded interval.

This can be generalized first to ${\mathbb{R}}^n$. We say that
$X\subseteq {\mathbb{R}}^n$ is bounded if there is a real number $M$
such that $\Vert x\Vert<M$ for all $x\in X$ and $\Vert\cdot\Vert$ is the
Euclidean distance between $x$ and $y$.

This condition is equivalent to the statement: There is a real number
$T$ such that $\Vert x-y\Vert<T$ for all $x,y\in X$.

A further generalization to any metric space $V$ says that
$X\subseteq V$ is bounded when there is a real number $M$ such that
$d(x,y)<M$ for all $x,y\in X$, where $d$ is the metric on $V$.
